definition:
A propositional formula is a CNF formula, meaning Conjunctive Normal
Form, if it is a conjunction of disjunction of literals (a literal is a
propositional variable or its negation). Hence, a CNF is a formula of
the form: $K_1 \wedge K_2 \wedge \ldots \wedge K_n$, where each $K_i$ is
of the form $l_{i1} \vee l_{i2} \vee \ldots \vee l_{im}$ for literals
$l_{ij}$ and some $m$ (which can vary for each $K_i$).

Example:
$(x\vee y \vee \neg z) \wedge (y\vee  \neg w \vee \neg u) \wedge (x\vee v)$.
